text: mr. maybe there are many groups Chinese
and others that try to come into
American companies American media groups
there was an attack on the New York
Times of course out of all of these
different groups how did you begin to
focus in on this one that you're calling
apt one or advanced persistent threat
number one as we were being hired to
respond to computer intrusions we ran
into apt one again and again and again
so we started observing an orienting the
apt one just because of the volume of
the attacks they were doing and how did
you narrow them down then to a specific
neighborhood just outside of downtown
Shanghai after responding to apt one for
years at over a hundred different
organizations you start to pick up
patterns such as over 98% of the time
when they were committing a computer
intrusion they're using the mainland
Chinese character set over 98% of the
time when they were doing their
intrusions in the u.s. companies they
were also using IP addresses from
Shanghai so I called 98% not an anomaly
at the same time we're always doing open
source of researching and what we had
learned is there's a unit a unit 61398
that's chartered with hiring people that
can speak English and be able to exploit
networks and no computer security and we
thought that was an interesting
combination and that unit just so
happens to be located in the same region
of Shanghai where we're tracking over
90% of the connections coming from what
you're saying is that what many people
saw as a shadowy Chinese group is
actually part of the People's Liberation
Army well I would think it is and it's
taking direction from the PLA and that's
why we've released this report is
there's all this public disclosure now
that it's China behind lots of these
intrusions I think it's also very
important for folks to realize it's not
just freelance people in China doing
these attacks it's attacks directed by
the government that means these attacks
can be more advanced they can be more
funded they can be more pervasive and
they will probably continue on abated it
could be the new normal
now one of the things you have done in
the course of the research that ended up
in the report that you're releasing is
that you have actually watched some of
these members of comment crew come into
systems and you have watched screens get
manipulated as that's happened whenever
we respond to intrusion we need to
really lock in on who these intruders
are so when there's a Chinese intrusion
and we're monitoring everything's in
plain view and we're at the victim sites
monitoring traffic coming in and out of
the victim so we're entitled to be there
it's okay that we're there and but it
just so happens sometimes when the
Chinese broke in then they would go
check their gmail accounts they would
use the infrastructure from victim
organizations to do some maybe of the
some private things or some other things
that they would do during the normal
workday and we got to observe those
things when these attackers come in do
you find that they are largely there to
steal data to steal intellectual
property or to takeover systems and try
to do some kind of an infrastructure
attack it's my opinion only from what
I've observed over the last eight or
nine years it's my opinion that they're
there to steal data now that mission can
always change and one of the things that
I've always observed is whether with the
Chinese when they hack a system they do
have access to destroy things they can
crush the system they can steal things
they can change things but they've
always operated with what I call rules
of engagement and they haven't far as I
know change the integrity or the
availability of the data they've only
changed the confidentiality of it if the
mission should change they do have all
the tools in place to be destructive
